TV Ads On Facebook

 

Facebook video advertising will take the form of 15-second television-style ads, according to Bloomberg's Edmund Lee. Depending on how large an audience the advertiser wants, the ads could cost up to $2.5 million a day. Facebook and Nielsen have already been working together for three years, says Lee, to provide advertisers the ability to compare television ads to video ads on Facebook. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001BjALoe6S8ghfEaQyR8H3uJUeZfEygDUF8w04GdO9XbbRdhhyX4vcgDVRWxaRBdD4UiskB87jEikv-Fj7oX-AzcjJNe7VhZJR9uitt-IBxOQBs-38qvEmtQhb93SJu88W6R3Qvn3DUqKYibwt8YxT3nSqiqse5KTgCLj9i7tzQgYD7RrU86tdjm4VSLN0jEa91g-ymPtjTiNtIIYJ0mmXe7Ln849EdpdKgZ6KxYL9qpE=> .

 

Don't Forget About Chicago

 

New York City may be the center of the media agency world, but Chicago stands to benefit from the Publicis-Omnicom merger as well. Two Publicis-owned media companies, Starcom MediaVest Group and VivaKi, are based in the Windy City, and expansion of those offices would be a boost to the local economy. "Starcom is the crown jewel of Publicis' media landscape, and VivaKi is the nerve center of its technology," said Shawn Riegsecker, founder of Centro. "If this transaction is truly based on technology, and VivaKi sits here, it would suggest that there's a great opportunity to create more jobs in Chicago." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001BjALoe6S8gi-yXXjoelPUYVzZaDXKtTNxTAlwDhyoA6Dqugm15v7zQiy8_OmaW0gSZZ42yITB8lWctUyk0LMx0bMGfIqN2BRc80BCNwcitVPl3itA1x41IsMBaY9cQwcXjZoITJVAkYj5STbRNunnMwM6XIo3jddvWC2HxE_507SHozYo3_7cFq8OX9OTeqGGbSgKGXPXnm1dctr9jRcRImiK1CrEHnh25AHqgnb2wBk3GFTuEgS0tCo7V5DmwpMUMPvEhloAkL38XdRyJzjdw==> .

 

Data $haring

 

With all the chatter about privacy and data sharing, Reputation.com plans to launch a product that trades rewards for personal information. According to the MIT Technology Review, the company was founded in 2006 and has received $67 million in investment funding. Not everyone thinks this product will work, such as Peter Fader, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Business, who said, "Despite the ways that companies delude themselves, demographics and other personal descriptors are rarely useful." He believes behavior is much more lucrative. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001BjALoe6S8gjHhxmrRUFhBXBy0aipqSzSAAV1kb0szTyXknjEEQ-KU4ffSRcC6k4odpiO8FFiXh8qQwOMmVOQ8U4npgB2OWpEq6h3nESGBrRwk828i1uoEHKjt6OM8bbBVQ9eaaWaAdc4OchN2h0gLzfgcc79xLBtbFxP11MhLl5eqdszegXVEdIHC24MYdInQ-gmO9BFUCG4Zq41fcuQhQ-OTkZvjpu_> .

 

Free Ads

 

Social media opens up an opportunity for marketers to repurpose user-generated content as ads, especially since studies show people trust their friends' opinions more than media companies'. According to PandoDaily, a new company called Olapic gathers photos from social networks and then gives them to e-commerce companies to use for ads. Some of the brands Olapic works with include Pepsi, Condé Nast and JetBlue. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001BjALoe6S8giwkpYtIx48Qs6NHjL5Us5CNDgtkDjDTrVl88hiufdM5hvDkel-rfkpWeNav6FOl_oVef_5Gq9ROE24_arQ5pYsvDA9E842eC2H3L-yI7LoPoH7TGXycm2RJZq_CO750ELaW1EVBUA_mU0SNmQX_XQSKwqueAQHaCZMuF0MFGAiZirPMWeyjVGnYgqGgdj0vyWkfVpJOH0OIc4C47QdicCQfX9rwaAsADSApEE7-hRuhw==> .

 

Twitter South of the Border

 

Twitter is launching promoted products in Peru and Ecuador after finding success in other South American countries, The Next Web is reporting. "We're seeing US brands turn to Latin America as an attractive emerging market to scale and monetize their business," says David Rayo, managing director of IMS Social. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001BjALoe6S8giPXgBRaZ_ebrpQ7lp6vKvcmV1j5pCddIVKuyQ2Su4vS5tlhaiDh5dCO7AWlMgFYnRtEk15TNCiyNwMRaxj-INUEJ3rdC6TSbnn8ybqjAtYL0dkrBTwnQmv_1_TSY2Ap8ctKWAy-q4BtlQosczpQWJXULpkaTK4jYRE6CsncJUUdPh56sCtizR5MMjelvJV2eo1-4IgzcNMZC94oFIR_IorypCohq9CwjDeH7MqK1FlUphCDcBJu8f77frsw5BwOn0rBAYf458Kw2wyacCQOFSq> .

Holy Data

 

One of the most popular Bible apps, YouVersion, could be worth $200 million because of its audience size and the data it collects, according to Slate. Despite spending $20 million so far on developing and maintaining the app, its creator has no intention to monetize. The data collected is used to help customize the user experience and is shared on a macro level with publishers. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001BjALoe6S8ghoLnFpqUni8rB7HbWGw4rdewdvgqM_Ag9hrIdsJhLBNTYtVH2e8oe-8j3sRKMgJV_ihDROh-AdMeC1abBTVDjrYVB9Gjt2smzdUgXqMQtdPBNqKJV4d8ACV0YanY-PiDkulqQCPxU5W4SAKm9euNDXhR5f4LEA-0WdGk9kIAy0TpaSv0enFS4g0RVsgGSsV65DdwzAnCEJBAlbN0xzbXbehzwBAjoQWCGQOGT0_Nr-J044h4Fwu_yaR_iyZoLdDc4=> .

 

Mobile Gains

 

An update to a comScore report shows that mobile traffic continues to increase, especially for companies like Pandora, Zynga and Groupon. The total audience for the top 100 sites has grown by 49% from smartphones and tablets. Some sites, such as Google and Vevo, saw a decrease in mobile-audience growth, even though the overall audience grew, due to people using the desktop sites. Read more on MediaPost <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001BjALoe6S8ggbMq3tiM_iXpJBgCAvv8_hfYga9OAymYIzWGYgcgGII-T-3obVmKDNV0L2i7m4e5LmqIWZ4TDpLa8mrSD3gBppePu2Qf5OHl23rkUp0xy2tEGfXGxk4XfGOqGQ3TlYat9Ch3bshxo3D1knWO6EJbJoHbkr3U2oOGzdYvqxWVHUUcIdEA6Zq-EdPA4oofxKR_HPaZJJojgQSodMfrRO_8XBkAiJEL-Xwpg=> .

Acqui-hiring Spree

 

Although nothing is confirmed yet, AllThingsD's Kara Swisher got word that Yahoo may acquire e-commerce app platform Lexity (AdExchanger Q <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVS4r82QkEPYKz1J8Zvwsi2WZ8QY1JeD3v5rE0mRsmfCpx8GlgrtASi_6SVeBI73s3lBD0xLqj-QX7kG6AIMDZ1WJ-fNpMkSi8Z261B_YvNnzpqzE3dVirRdj5g3vnFcR0sYJzGlUfs3VrR4mcJEvdqC> &A 2011). This would mark the 19th acquisition since Marissa Mayer took over as CEO, and some speculate the acquisition spree is really an effort to buy talent. If the acquisition comes to fruition, Lexity CEO and former Dapper (acquired by Yahoo in 2010 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVTbCSTNp8G9_DuSas3cvj0nwrIIBkNCSy4nR0z9-xbFEpwxkSEhZhamePyaArOyCoOePyN--HkkKPSlxzULUxCF8wTg8E37KAt7eiXhxNNq1vishHC5jqravYxGRHk_Llzpi76uF5i11dwyLClc0egr> ) exec Amit Kumar would be back at Yahoo for a third time. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVQdcH3gTzVgfGQFBGFWhYfpOWXEoTFZ9emp_5dL0mDpjclHjbf2mrDBkEPsaEtv-x3EJE0lgqfmv8T_ikU6FTnpRCgKd7J0LJOSs71yW_dc7wVkuQSNus_P9NY13JFLFIHyZrLd5mtzEYSAb5-QmtsVwrQC0nUUQhLuWm1A48xW07JGVmKQXH5AfgOmqC1_AqWoSlXwQuGq6g==> .

 

Above-The-Fold Mythology

 

According to Adweek, a new Washington Post study revealed that scrolling ads, which followed users for seven seconds, performed better than static above-the-fold ads. Viewability is in play here, too. "[Marketers] say, I want above-the-fold impressions," said Jeff Burkett, senior director of ad innovations and client services at the Post. "I know enough now that above-the-fold doesn't mean viewable. There may be some ads that are below the fold that perform better." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVTa4pxFS6IOCeQH1BXlpb58CuChauPSvchR_UWIdX9hFchsWc8ybZp4RSVZgeKCTn9r7OdS9jqhNUdPdbxkuOk8Asr3mEGRq5k8TknUFQKiyJkf0yy8Q47VchOHcyxEsHPD9hgJ5fmO_HrdjZAI7LVJMR6LclvyHECEe8rQYQkWE4JQvQ15ndDxvxbe8hNw_oAoIE4ivd0SzA==> . Also in Adweek, Tremor Video has put banner ads in its proverbial rearview mirror. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVRbyBeBWMDh53R-WO9XmXmgQ67QABpYj2EwxTrcPrB8c_dRkUGwdrRMmWVMvpjBXudTYf4ag1ZYb1Y5MEizm_y3FUwNztDGjlLVLo8995Td5yuYXxmao1aNReD4ga23LcGzazu_6aSiQQaAa63iQMOpy596Ko4nAgw_tuBFEEzkfbAIZcXpKFVl7GEScFOC98PoBbFyYjlbfPoopTzZq_y3> .

 

Loyal Cereal

 

For a large company like Kellogg's, tracking consumer data was difficult until the company introduced a loyalty program that allowed them to track specific purchases. Let the retargeting begin. Called Kellogg's Family Rewards, the program has consumers enter a code found on the package in exchange for points. The codes are linked to each product under the Kellogg's brand umbrella. "It's not the only [loyalty] program like that, but generally speaking companies don't do that," said Ron Park, VP-retail consumer-goods industry lead at Merkle, in Ad Age. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVQ6qfkTHXzYXzeXpPT6RXYuX7aKR44gg8so0y3JE4lF5-ZGhpy09YKnTQ5mu2dCEyIvihUCUfs9j-p-wdLaB17uN2Qsr2gZL-7NBcOYwjcpBUKvqIXMX51p_MrkDTX1QPmaBUuB7YD_ZKadktQye8G8i0GWCeof-IL_M2S4K_m9kSMuus_S7hr1DZO4q17EtzS2WLVnMwkLvJTvBrn96ukP> .

 

Mobile Email Kinks

 

Mobile advertising is the newest advertising frontier and it seems email still has some issues that need to be ironed out. According to a study done by Juniper on behalf of Campaigner, and a MediaPost article, consumers are most unhappy with poor design and irrelevance. Furthermore, 37.2% of respondents couldn't tell if mobile email marketing had any impact on them. Read more in MediaPost <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVTWb7eeyQHFkvZXdgloQo_Xf1dWe6gBTJOMVPIgof9_YvShfOMUYh0mi1idCkvDNY6u6FcjVPU4cruF81KOJDyEyTpaWqM65BG3SmerVaWKa6EuUeGeaEy1qsWansfN85SwVAbQjW9TbEsH7MOatkom25EYmtvVitopZvZvNBx15xO7xIxVidjbswd_j1b9FbxFpJMylQ8w2RqjcwYNX2rpTmgFouWAmUTMe5vYveocU0zGHikvgpcC> .

 

Privacy Trend

 

A Forrester study, which hasn't been publicly released yet, reveals a growing trend among companies wanting to appear privacy-friendly. Jeff Roberts likens it to the eco craze in the 1990s. GigaOM got its hands on the survey results and found that out of 1,053 adults, only 35% were not using some sort of privacy setting on their browsers. Of course it's possible, as Roberts points out, that the people surveyed were more aware of privacy settings than the majority of the population -- some of whom are still using dial-up. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVTJNy5H9QN4SJG-QNO0YZx_KQe52V2hXh1VQnAwDrabqlhoISeeQFr6U16d5BadaUj7jMMWbaEZpoacN2YorTm9juQUJmgtjXI_w1RFJZHjYOYJlW2RlghT6YLWWKbsg41iND1bXJMg3Q2CFs5rJuIJZZ2goajJzvVjMQ7uq-2N-0LRV_c4f0aH_FSz30TLr7TT218028DMkuDaqTnuwVo8O7IC_VrsLbPVwreZQJCeKR-ZzaoR2-MP> .

Musical Data

 

Data is a lot of things. For Vienna Teng, it's a muse. After an internship with Acxiom, Teng was inspired to compose a song about the company, according to Arkansas Business. Some of the lyrics include: "somebody hears you," "you don't have to hide" and "let our formulas find your soul." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVTU_qYi8vs3XOkhSUJIotBtV5yrxHBuOFWE2p1m6jEoSel0N4f46CJYyoU9f4k1rMUpDfZDxzzSy1Lz71CSkOQ9Y9tU-lDotO0V5QK0sKnIYCVUKS1Z_vvJDkSaqFUZI-bKgLDcCbAbRAt39DbfrKz_sloxy5zqR4mZVCzMpnnHoAMIA06_NgWpYddqolgpXfY=> . Listen here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Eo-TOn0LxVR4qngRjI6G1C29xwscxujdd7GoNYNnyh2YiL89k4ARDlFlEQZTDl2l7I4MnZci7Nzai7GHvteEz44TI97kLSl7AayiqEw8TQGsLY260aYvhSiqCNJS7RJORzthB_6esqOMARkheWHoXta07VwYvSF1ysiRaXXue8x1ZqbmKqEyzA2Ny1OJIICjZhxEQLyxRjuB5ghz6jIbQh9fmkyOfNgsaTACgaI8fCpM4uwHep9deEAdpqR1pvjbr7BsnXBpWeeP5J9eQySsATri4Jy4aGxwtURnnJ1UNj_gjdK1uYdhfJoEGccjCZrzdtHusihYNXHxz94HHq7xLA==> . Scale Counts For...

 

In a press release late Sunday, Dominic Proctor, Global President of GroupM, WPP's media investment unit, threw the following barbs after the Publicis and Omnicom merger announcement <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TUbckMW6bM6lLbCJKb5P8QQC4zIvnBTYoZAaFQOVW3wfEelzmCk2hWgRS5MAqEeN2erJyiH82JaKoyslVId48nCfLwQAky6wXyIZoXG1ep-I9q3xF99PiMAftsDSy69pDIWuRezl9nYeMbd66xhXaxwrisUnY14uJyPuJ8Dht52XEucHPYBXiu-0G1gDJ2ssMPI1U0AxnGCqwd-mCQ9x5r6QIDEctFGAo5Y8fqNqz410Prgh2nEnYg==> : "This is an interesting move. They are making it clear that a primary motive for the merger is achieving scale in media buying. However, neither Omnicom nor Publicis was able to bring their investment teams together effectively as individual companies, so it will be fun to see if they can now do it together. Getting scale in media investment management is critical for clients, but it only works if it all joins up. We welcome a competitor in this space. Media investment management relies heavily on scale, but scale counts for nothing if it continues to be disparate."

No Longer Keen

 

Yahoo!7 has decided not to join other Australian publishers in creating a premium advertising marketplace, according to Mumbrella. The exchange would have consisted of Yahoo!7 along with News Corp Australia, Fairfax Media and Mi9. "There was an assumption made that Yahoo!7 would be keen. We would welcome with open arms any premium publisher who wanted to be in there. But with Yahoo!7, discussions didn't get far," said one executive. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TUbckMW6bM5c2p34yGRQREBo6DV8kkEz2BXGdKiv7yJYP2hITVStdMg4EJr9vRmIkmg57B-LpedvsR3ru3_zwUbJmcousnt5LY-GgpT7XN7a4v1UJIIuAEaBXsB4_uNmc6-YrOKBNqgnANdfo4KCenouC3HELr-65k6ZqqqFx8Fra8lndioc_BzwZ8zCaQaSaJ9cmzm4mIM=> .

 

Bridging The Gap

 

Mobile ad tech company Drawbridge isn't letting a lack of mobile cookies stand in its way -- the company announced a new tool for retargeting that works across apps and the mobile web."Many marketers have already acquired millions or even tens of millions of users; they now need to turn their attention to tools and techniques that allow better engagement marketing towards this user base," says Drawbridge founder and CEO, Kamakshi Sivaramakrishnan. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TUbckMW6bM5agiKHtVArJYiFQNnB7ZFdOnbXDS5YDqN2iujRMVRxRtXuiRaLU1U3Uxy7Zll3BwsdoW8tzSJyEocqJIRWPGd58ygrghfSQv5zG4KdLHJNZXV9XhpFvhLnSqYrtAqGKeJ9ZIsH7LXv_ofmLaaR7n9mQc6GwYdtf-A=> . And, more on TechCrunch <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TUbckMW6bM4H2VkJdEbf0HQ1kHv26EKoD9v8OTmbM23gK-JwimAVTA9XtTeOlmfwyp8khgc_Pb7DzYO01srlhr-766I2OaoEr8XZnC1NhlBdpodwDGvgW3SDGYkiuZXLvxu4tgQZMIhepqCWKdoYJMF5QY7HjCEZPGjDkilKL4EtBu-Nui8lSefxEGRRVkF0> .

 

Mobile Privacy Promises

 

The Department of Commerce's National Telecommunications and Information Administration drafted a voluntary code of conduct for app developers, according to Forbes. If implemented information such as what data is being collected (browser history, financial info, location, etc.) and who it's being shared with (ad networks, carriers, etc.) would be disclosed to users. Although there is no real obligation for developers to adhere to the code, if they do publicly commit to the code they can be held legally responsible by the FTC. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TUbckMW6bM4nxRg_A4NwuToM6maaW7ym0aR92YU17nT47Zs7qisYobwqbHHrstGdDYb2YEv3K0-6XkVdFGBl9Mqwkob1_Wwt6UbeoBRXx2rm5yGeQWiXuSMzBJ93lhw1qUruipcLzFmeiFK_TsUhWPvZtTxkdS8z4M5S9I9Y0nr93zycLs7A1dHBVXnSQJ9i20b0ZP8j9-rArgWSu3VZfNILuTDXPf8Ps-9I1ZSj4ExMiJ4hbczlDhNmnnRVFCrX7sYx9yDgrBjfVBNYtiUhNphmXF85jWFNkqDqkmoAUPk=> .

  _____  


Programmatic Ireland

 

Irish broadcasting company RTÉ is selling nearly all of its inventory programmatically using the Adap.tv platform, according to a press release. "Programmatic trading can command high rates and provide a cost-effective solution for broadcasters looking to generate revenue outside their core market," said Brian Fitzpatrick, managing director at Adap.tv Europe. Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TUbckMW6bM4PiVWkf_4bznsQF-ClKRJyWRHjujavNI-Pks6bODRQKs_9j3YCoDBmqprzjEqX-ea7ryW6lTxJxZyLDJYNi7_nRAqksDET3CMqP3F6Ua2LU3OBWM47Wg8a> . Read more coverage here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TUbckMW6bM4N5UX-TQPtvCtbnt1G7C0F-xXFbMM_qbZjYo_u6JGHTvDo3Yf_XweR2Z_38wkhl-cUDwPVC1jIEqNIlWVJN1YSn_2gg65G9WHUbw4C2kPTCYgnkHds4DUKTnSuaXOvnxYnOThIykKlnkTyDcsO40pIirAuUXwWO3V3wGtisiVWiQ1vaUqWY4KaR-LTIUQHNwh2JligniCPqOJ_Yp4ITkeX> .

 

Private Pinterest

 

Following in Twitter's privacy footsteps, Pinterest is allowing users to opt-out of being tracked, according to the New York Times. From a Pinterest blog post, "We're excited to offer everyone a more personal experience, but we also understand if you're not interested. We respect Do Not Track as an option for people who want to turn off this collection of browsing activity from other sites." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TUbckMW6bM5-yHBnolrixsnh7IzDGaBrS5rhbhzx2nKkF720hXNk77jkFx7e-zg8veJc5KxtyHoZmxP-HmC5vxH4N5-15rHjDnVFTQWc_GYKoCWwyFkax-59-QjUbDvoz2sOjH7tulTE2z5MOb1pfIH-W10osGcAfZJhS8BhDfKnt69Yofo67H27bBwt5JoLGrdvnoHlRIm3Ss1s-t_EuIEaNRv5UQsaKMMB3THQpV4=> .

 

You've Been Malvertised

 

MIT Technology Review turns lemons into lemonade with a post detailing how it was duped by a masquering malvertiser pretending to be a Gilt Groupe rep named "Nick Sampson." After serving his ad, "We investigated and quickly understood that our ad was directing people to a fraudulent clone of the real Gilt site. 'Nick' was likely part of a scam to steal credit-card numbers." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001TUbckMW6bM6wnuu4WatzJTggh-lutvrmQj2ZCL6iD-RsdKOe-aE4epqjmOajB2jzIOAn3UJ7NNhsLKw3p5w8eLyFQIRUMcm-YDVVYHcID7l4iXVaa8mSmyX4_7EHU_i94_LlGQ4_sxvMAvmrDTTVt2A9ykjTAtmMzb5LZ2uLy9XAYDM5vG6u7KL4W41gkPg3AKLe1MJ8tjW4OpmJKGYabZJ1J8D3vNWq>

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>   

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodjl7RqFpyxKqHYwmiZ3ADwRbzWay0XyBCm_Y6qxxlPhJn9GF3cRX3LN5EHJyjqCAWLyW9mpJEVJRrfvLUK72VZ2_FFQgutH4TPhnGHy3MUiEXjtHSO91AK9tKCV_AXYmXc=> .

 

Global Display

 

In a not-so-surprising report, Nielsen found display advertising is growing by leaps and bounds while more traditional advertising is decreasing in spend. From the release: "Display Internet advertising, though measured in a smaller subset of countries, grew a significant 26.3 percent for the first quarter. Display internet ad growth was particularly impressive in the Asia-Pacific (33.2%) and Latin America (48.2%). Internet even bucked the trend in Europe, boasting growth of 10.4 percent." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodgTY7O2GLMikKa-6R-rXWdp8l5cPzNaXsQRrSI_EP8tdnNLmK2eUYKICYEc9YZAEGheKestc5OrOESlEys-s5ah7-n-kxri89Hrlk8_iuxnQP1uZb2hIuKwXeiZ9Xi_uUcdAcCASIIymjcN0V1XHDL9pbqf7CFOB7Uafjz4hxpNv8PznuUJpF1zDLUfXV_WYfpTRLj4HENpMygapWK2amajY3wMzCn0Ohil0xxqEYbsUQ==> .

 

Measuring Success

 

With the surge in popularity of native advertising comes on important question: how can success be measured? It turns out, according to Ad Age and an OPA study, publishers are using familiar metrics such as engagement, time spent and traffic; similar to how web pages are measured. "There's a lot of confirming what one's gut would have thought," said Pam Horan, OPA president. "Many of the metrics are more in line with how publishers are measuring the impact of their content." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodjY7uFUf7bLZ9VlNkeX93Yjm9DzXduLstRId-tYYtbp8YKfqsozE_9-oLsRJk5aWBF41dT1NoVbrUs8Mumc15nbwKOE3n6jsjKvWUPtdZlg-ULG44esYyycKhrWFa8bYKRHkwpx7BBxQr8hNWo-yh1EXuhQF5PW_q3TlXL9pLRnSKFQd1jyMqqf3Bj8SnjyP2zeMYxUarKgj8ZdImHiQISC> .

 

Quality Assurance Upgrade

 

The IAB released its Quality Assurance Guidelines 2.0 yesterday. According to the IAB's Steve Sullivan in the release, "The new QAG 2.0 represents the best efforts of the IAB and member companies to ensure that the highest standards of trust, compliance, quality and integrity are continually met for all stakeholders to keep pace with the constant change that drives our business." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodiRkBYqFxNOAuvZPRXlOwxrks0RAVj0EZekYuZyjIOzVDjLSPIm4s2rQ6JG2hC9f-16mFwyODHKHdfn1ZEV0uhe1o1qqnZHs2DzSVuhjZn-MBRAUnqWWfElto64MDsLKuq-DOnOc1OFxWVgx5NuIhUV7v_k11niX56VIA3qkR0q3P2wJ3sEhf9tY4xqdZYoRYr-4oNAkC38cPZ3vgm8HxCvLRaozTPceqo=> .

 

Man vs. Machine

 

The big fear with programmatic is that it could take away human jobs, but Tim Nichols and Myles Younger don't think that's the case. In a ClickZ Q&A, Younger points out that algorithms are written by humans, and there's no substitute for human creativity. "The tools and tactics are getting more automated, and you've got a bunch of pretty well-automated point solutions, but creating clever, well-informed combinations of the available options is still something you need humans for," Younger said. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodjA57dYOjTqPUpgtKlRTO270ebU6lt7AgHQukcI_hVep_mvgk5yRodOpuHOgsxcQuVJ7Lr-71tNODGM8by2GRLF0UAovmAdbYYCzvNTns3-HhyKgsvHDWOdxiKopjg7vVjhnopDzavol2KArfOgpRlsud0_ogsvUl0MJUHbsalxrctNBlKqldjjY7rBvoZT8uSznxdMBlgglqpHYohYrnf4bT5jplDcvT-E2uRZFEEviQ==> .

 

Real-Time Partnership

 

Real-time marketing platform SHIFT has partnered with programmatic mobile platform Gradient X, according to a press release. "Combining Gradient X's technology with our social advertising tools, we now offer the only platform where advertisers can reach their customers across all mobile environments," said James Borow, Co-founder and CEO of SHIFT. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodheaKyEBfnayzbfQk4THEh8lM3uv8CrsVXaHL58o5q30OmkgUY6S-qx4BQ-uJ15Ml9whxGy_CVvxswgy3CMRl-ciS_0a9V12flHg33tDI6VDYu3na10ac9rzDcdsWMW5FrJusMoB9DMrVVbPIk9MRDpFWOPBoiMD0g=> .

When An Impression Isn't

 

Facebook's 10-Q financial report yields some explanation around when an ad impression is an ad impression - or not. (FB has provided the same info previously <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodgExzrGitk044sGsSEtvp2dmLwOLmZTcCaZWNZNmMa7fYQz_fK3l0BBOEdweeGXfA1ei2-TExd2UNfwYoCVZxfcfDqRHZ0xovtLyWhx58cHMIdrAukk5a97w3Bwm7MoQJdMBi24quwMRg==> .) But, take a look: "Whether we count the initial display only or every display of an ad as an impression is dependent on where the ad is displayed. For example, an individual ad in News Feed that is purchased on an impression basis may be displayed to users more than once during a day; however, only the initial display of the ad is considered an impression, regardless of how many times the ad is actually displayed within the News Feed to a particular user." CPMMMM. See the 10-Q on the SEC's site. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodhMMuy1wcjSnkM_ZKqaBN7zpFNNdRuDkpcJqgYAor2l0Gawl8WxSvAzjxD9zsGIALafMPV--xuJMcnM8D5pJXl8IZH3PTAEGH4oDYvRRX_1rfF7UlqAlE3C3hG_jO_9N6Zndcpmju9wntHEw68DgrxKduuAPLug3rU=> 

 

A Mozilla Experiment

 

In its self-proclaimed quest to bring transparency and user control to the Web, Firefox-creator Mozilla is testing a new setting around content personalization. In a blog post, Justin Scott, product manager at Mozilla Labs, describes the setting: "let's say Firefox recognizes within the browser client, without any browsing history leaving my computer, that I'm interested in gadgets, comedy films, hockey and cooking. As I browse around the Web, I could choose when to share those interests with specific websites for a personalized experience." Read more about it here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodjqNCW4jXU1JmL7Eoj0I2RdP7PUAKz0c2_em3TQNV18bEnN4h7zfT3zRqaffkr3EOvHdarLOwW5ARS4abCO9FKCUBrs7vAlt4hzf6dGAEE_iZmZPRIzCRjytbG5JMjAUUjCKMlGHy-QgFIf-0Tjtzt2Av17cHObUwUPiPYVb8zpjcz1TFbVcKPdwEK37y5clWC5BhRDe8Dg9A==>  and here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001--eqXctmodijfRraHJd_4jB22RySKtkz5bnR7cB3BemnU7GygKA0Es0z8sUwxSWaMj8_wVZyokNZAx2p1IDItL0D1PtyYcb4f0ZwDJD2SZlSXPTgGIO4GwZGdKP6G1O3k9j8v2xuhaH2wUolnrliWtmeWP78yZ8Euy6DsWhAoSJP-gi6236AvQ==> .

*	Does The Online Ad Industry Need A 'Programmatic Upfront?' <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95gljGZCXSCTsTNIxfKp9zHoupouB4MGwPpM8anKZnEDrcjD8NUZXY1UQ5xVfq_FWrrRNJm3u6XDtS9kg2ztT9WY_DCPc3IoVpdHms3T8V3Z-7ZEJL5fuT7tNptucs-RbvzNB6p87EX4ePb_WIqFZsFEkLofHMFFD0MieURhrZkiuWJBhPfW4A0q>  

*	Bill Wise, CEO, Mediaocean: It's a smart move by AOL for a different reason than you may think: All the real-time bidding intermediary players are now talking about moving upmarket to premium programmatic." 
*	Frank Addante, CEO, The Rubicon Project: "A programmatic upfront is a natural promotional device to accelerate the programmatic requirement for direct orders." 
*	Brett Wilson, CEO, TubeMogul: "Given that premium digital video advertising is scarce, upfronts make sense because they offer advertisers and publishers alike predictability around pricing and scale." 
*	Tod Sacerdoti, CEO, BrightRoll: "Selling programmatic packages upfront makes a ton of sense in the digital video advertising business, as inventory is naturally supply constrained and certain audiences (such as in-market, retail, key geographies and retargeting) will generate premium rates throughout Q4." 
*	Jeff Green, CEO The Trade Desk: "While this is progress, and it is good for buying platforms like ours, they're not likely addressing the inherent problems with upfronts -- which is that most people don't know what they're buying."  
*	Bryan Wiener, CEO/chairman, 360i: "This is a highly dynamic market set by buyers and sellers and a long-term commitment isn't necessarily aligned with what makes programmatic work so well..." (visit AdExchanger)

The Dreaded Restructure

 

Syncapse announced major layoffs, according to CBC News, just one year after its Clickable acquisition <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95i1_zld_ADLu1aIVdWFv8KxxaLKBSM8wjrHy2tpQ9XLDwcZutQWzj1CAAUeaGHeXS50UUlg8hUvFlPLcPuFk2mjEfpZETcHBg-rDSRhSJqk6hv8GHKsG9r1MlW0bB5x2RD3sWh8Y3L5IceRSxdxFhEfCCj1D5HW-3mKXJbqv2DbBLtVQfR-jRLm5cH3Vo00ofdhKUVGtPydxQ==> . The social media marketing firm has been around since 2007, and had around 110 employees as of the end of last year. "Despite our best efforts, the organization lacks the resources to move forward successfully and as such must enter a period of restructuring," Syncapse founder and CEO Michael Scissons told employees in an email. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95gAS3BRxa1hoQp4kTf5r0zGXAK_kadYrQ4UIKSzVZG9GJNf5g9HlIEXX-c_1j-expsO4HWljW1VmDLBRCSBs9d7LfC3Fmvp4zr7iC_cGbwwVDvrGan-uBpy1Cl44MCSM7gxr5luzcvP__3aDL0nGOgRwJc1M-4_YrNo3-gQ60h6FJatAYdMlvsLr05lxFTvWA4MeTHJNrWQ1g0D14IsFhZP> .

 

New Mobile Codes

 

The Digital Advertising Alliance and the Network Advertising Initiatives both rolled out mobile privacy guidelines for their members yesterday. The codes, which were created separately, require member companies to notify consumers that data is being collected about them for advertising purposes and to allow them to opt out of receiving behaviorally targeted ads on mobile devices. Read more about the DAA's code here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95hwHV-KRJiYacFRfFzFA3-I9RMMbzj58vqCEPrDdEVC5_ZsndswWbvmU27hgKLuMvwp-ElGT42PeQEbKLl6c9215YC9VjRbZ5O29LmRRCSsognC2ETHysUB>  and the NAI's code here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95jACwXDeh48P91iX76jdgj-YdeSkztbxt6vfngEUiFzVfLXKVgV7GZPWyt6Pq0W-zAvpsnfG8S-h_Omt_YUAiyOyVrQys9aVbGtj2QjGLKIguGOznPX13HSf3j4419oSG8ZAuT4TSWuG3q_w05RJWBhI1kCd9cdhTTm7uiQksPu8vxnEPgcpWr1ji8y6Fe4l9XD_--X6-RrhfngWc-W35rHBtLlYJ3oLUwtqSupApeyOg==> . And, download the DAA  <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95i8aU3LokDrAvdGgBd-sTu7Xs_yPI4waZFt1Lc_LwPQqjGTbJNBOpBrCZ39IueiDDOer8SOEscXluofh9V5pT8lgXZu4IciXjoOuFQNsgTP-Wp82lsNqRxDoLiAgkLVF3w8rIstfAsmQg==> "principles" here (PDF).

 

Retail Buying Tech

 

Yesterday, Walmart Labs bought website performance company Torbit, according to VentureBeat. The small company will be responsible for making Walmart's sites faster and more efficient across all devices. Walmart is also looking to hire around 150 tech employees, which makes sense given the vast ecommerce market and stiff competition from sites like Amazon. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95giA5Lw3-SwSzt88dqnhDobNZjQP9whkH0Mo66KcXpVWupzapLl-wyNY-KXnd606iMdoBHeLf7W24IHn66zSkr9AALAJ02_v64i6xRIi9zFhib6jAXomWZN5g-8FM_qyps6J6EQKTmHmDa94L6Y5jO6Ywn5NluGkS4=> . Buying startups is not new for Walmart Labs. The Walmart subsidiary bought OneRiot in 2011 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95h0WdRyK4MYsYWfE0wdVFeO79P3SQZkzaUPMZgWuIlY9un3VBGFih4BLlAkiGh_DTH59RIwuRSR8qlgEOmzBN18qAPCQCTAFC4TNqECA0KO9QvqzMOUZ43vIYAGrXaW2FOlpbOlSCd6EF0UVVmYPhZfGgTR64YbN19B_652qHx7nQ==> , for example.

 

China's Amazon

 

Amazon is an e-commerce powerhouse in the U.S., but Chinese-based Alibaba could pose a serious threat to the company if it expands worldwide. According to Forbes, Alibaba handled gross sales of $170 billion in 2012, more than Amazon and eBay combined. Global expansion is definitely on the table for the company, along with an IPO. Yahoo, which has 24% of Alibaba shares, stands to benefit a lot from a public Alibaba. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95iJ4N7PTq-WFF13kZoxjHgfxb2q7UgVAw7HHrO2j6enRFWfsbySWXBrKIXvdH1Y9PjhiQjCeXOf4nq3g-ox3F6yJX9vFivGFyblKjiBQFodSM57ZpOJpPaqFtCDUULCIfib7t29wqWSduTpyH1QHENvgS3JENLYmxTqX7A79UgixnYTWlhInisGxG1AlnQ3KO9ne5gdIETjR8nP4iCKZhqY9GYDm6tL6vPvHBrmyzp09w==> .

 

State Of The Internet

 

Akamai released its first quarter state of the Internet report, estimating that the number of unique Web users connecting to its platform during the quarter to be well over one (1) billion. "[The report] shows continued positive growth in terms of Internet and broadband adoption worldwide. We have seen overall increases in average and peak connection speeds along with greater broadband penetration on both a quarterly and annual basis," said David Belson, the report's editor. "However, the levels of malicious activity we've observed show no signs of abating, as evidenced by the ongoing rise in DDoS attacks. Read the report <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95hHGsNbvKCx7-C-cICy9u_uAIhkt1RDDYEq0QsHP8os4XBkBg1-TDZm1TUSJixeIDL3jUTuVEFpuHMrtjKoCynMlzu_k9Z2UCAuDsyciDNogwcY8HimUzdawWJO-96e0mK9ERrk7Jqc2vJsQYQV3zmiM6NIg8jVfZxYDco9V8PS-tAeWuZ-khT1pxM_aJe98CM_Vwg18qzkV_DvBcq1Y_2DR31UWq6omEwTWmygilv4qg==> . Download the Figures (.zip) <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95gcykJ1bpLeCRvuzWpHlwuJhghJN0sYLWGcB9MzPjW7vIZq_DpcRJcjjAAoyYy9SId_3AHpFm-kReuLa4770zASlUzL6ZFOn9JYJCe92sx61eJJeqzmdpTjZLU2oQMhsK1E5Sv8yCwQV1LEQMZlqkY3> .

Feeding Display

 

Chango says it's in the Facebook news feed, too, with its search retargeting product. See the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95hR8mj_Vsba-LBMZMW62B_5eYUPiAUiFsswAebR-2gvXWB8_yB5rkKjcXGJl2-HuwKw32PRi_7iTVI0vd6-Ahhb9Z9gwChdryfrTaveETroJeY0DI847k1N9-boW6kaJBXh3AtwoE1kLYaaX0fS4QqVJnlv_68tIIVa_rpPIqzO60ClN2VI5MlR98p3LfIJjhkUEsWQUOp91EgujFQR3op_d8k21VzmPSOBNfC-jO6CCA==>  Meanwhile, Chango marketer Ben Plomion tells discusses what he sees as the myths of display ads in a think piece on ClickZ. In myth #4, he debunks the notion that display is expensive: "The average CPM for remnant inventory is between $1 and $2. Even in super competitive verticals such as finance, display can often be a cheaper (and more efficient) acquisition channel than SEM." Read it. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95i28W5O29siDIp7Zajb8qZPjKpSkEN5HY_DZBz0oTDYhWzr8qbkQVHdZZYqV4xHZGxRgUd5wrZmflihMPHr4Uty8xIBoV61mlllaO_9rJzYxNO5FFJk31nWMspHrm8L-nsBLwhmrQR9OnGSBQnioF17pTi0Lkh5LrIObVZ-ExPiGaCvjsWYDqQbGEx7teKhP5dFvyRWpbUPkw==> 

 

Marketer RTB

 

Kellogg's digital director for Europe Matt Pritchard tells UK ad trade The Drum that it "has 'reduced wastage' and improved cost-per-engagement across various brand campaigns during the last 15 months of RTB activity, as a result of being able to deliver the right ad to the right target audience and the right time, which RTB enables." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95g_2dftO26edZQVFWCzHdDyjBu8izv8fqYlBLpDZHfwJDgscYcksPGqXkBa1jqaHpyi4RX09LSKeRQdnKlTSPBvq37VMEuUfaNpG08mlZ5anBUm5w-lDWCdsQ1-iZ1bycMI1QuBJyRf3UnOsDBuJ9cUfFe3m0_trYDQ-00oJup2jwxL9bCAnxs_K-Hkx33LThUgf7YM2cx-IJnUXrA5bGTbUpURb6uBx3288AlvnBqfq--upm4aKmZ-> 

 

Ad Tech Bubbles

 

On Digiday, DMP Lotame's COO Adam Lehman is emphatic: "There is no ad tech bubble." He continues, "Notwithstanding the shots taken at ad tech as a segment, it actually presents a lower risk profile to investors than many other segments, since ad tech companies are often quick to generate revenues, sustain solid margins and can, in many cases, achieve profitable scale without needing to be the sole or lead player in a category." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001bhicucYN95jwkY_tw5qK499f7MP09MOMIb84r6tvZK7L0XEWZOHKdx8U3OpALEv32n3D-at_xjaxjR_r2gvbqItOQvvXAq7dZpORI9W2DdSMs_9gZPigh8frp5ksh5AFt_IdH-dJQitmbGF6nFZfHlSzsZIEAf0SHGPUYCx18Hk=> .

Everyone Wins

 

It shouldn't be programmatic versus premium, David Jacobs, SVP publisher sales at AOL Networks, attempts to explain in a column for Ad Age. It's all about knowing which to use and when. He writes, "For advertisers and publishers alike, a fully integrated strategy combines both programmatic and premium approaches. Programmatic tools, engaged intelligently, simply take the busy work out of routine buying." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ttLvyLuecAYk2BPgzXyLyTMXxgHeH8TZck7Jwl6DvBDRJ7UU-XQrAVrH4FD9skgfHEqdBB5jwlf3fOcbH4igt04P8LUEyDuKIpWQa-2b2deAtv0y-nEMsLLGNeG5jeGHV4elj5hyVcbU7wbhUVRr3sSMCVTtXkulpsxj1nLpp3Mf8-_xwNLbCQ==> .

 

Hotel To Go

 

Consumers are more frequently delaying hotel bookings until they're in transit, and Best Western hopes to capture some of that market with mobile advertising. According to Mobile Commerce Daily, the company uses geo-fencing and location data to serve ads to people, which allow them to book hotels from their phones. So far Best Western is seeing success, with the highest CTR being 2.3%. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ttLvyLuecAbzi4ikXUhq0wizkxz3TIY7MwhF8id_j-1-T9siFyNs9CuTJUNUpyih6AOmf5zi-8t2Ui_U6kwPze4s5ro31Uk9WI_k1ouWhusd83S_d2TdATCGoBCMPCrxitGmkeGfEAojrhcz7iKHK_63zTzkgH4RIdmN7OzSeclXHXzxUYG_wxcEc2vn-eIsyrNAgVhAyNE=> .

 

RTB For All

 

SiteScout announced the launch of an RTB API via press release, which will be open to developers and businesses immediately. "SiteScout has always been about empowering marketers, agencies and advertisers, with an accessible programmatic ad buying platform," said Paul Mokbel, CEO of SiteScout. "This is why we launched this API: to give them the right tools to create their own RTB-powered ad products." Read the release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ttLvyLuecAY7m10NlUnX79Nn5vxSZXE-V6tlyeaJZhVisOF71_r4OkFBb2c4xaNaZDpKy4hVCE6s4c8kpFlQIdKbvVmF9n_C3A_iJ8f5bWdkPyVIEKkqqRc6iGU0N15WMPLRx1arZ3v9S9gzmyPIKeHEnHenYuzPvXOEJePFGiL-93jV0MS9JMDgEFPlE552a6RE5DYZHokDJjsf1JwC89ALK8de94GvJZ7r9XYr74bQBug3XLvmYdbjqq9IzOufeUgT_f9o6UM=> .

 

Omnicom Part 3

 

Omnicom Group is creating a third media agency, according to Ad Age, but there is no official word from the company yet. It wouldn't be the first time a holding company created additional agencies, in fact Omnicom is the last holding company with fewer than three agencies. According to the article the company has been reaching out to executives to try and poach a CEO for a third agency. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ttLvyLuecAbMQzCTSQYr3jHU_g08VkyyNXhkHognPJ9kSql6yZwvv8bUQCfHjDtccN5gpPRpOG10ptshLgqaRQmwbCUFcUHNa3Ig5njb9XtCfnWFEXl1hYSBFkefHBxd_sO0xY427Zp6PkSk25vX08cWdBf2Nc9ROlNtI74Di-jO21SbLPpi0zN84YfvKJaMAEpfRWnmibMhQ14OaEDiytkg_olMLZZv> .

Right Media Reviewed

 

Mike Shields listens for criticism about Yahoo's Right Media Exchange - and finds plenty - in an article on Adweek. He also quotes Media6Degrees COO Andrew Pancer who offers hope, "Yahoo has fantastic inventory, and it makes Right Media a must buy for us. If they had other good inventory, it would be as simple as a flick of a switch to turn it on." There's only one publisher on RMX that matters - Yahoo. And even then, challenges remain. Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnudufdXgZuxD8MvEHUO1H4pC_crfRAbYJjtPo313VUCPosCG6q9jQcHBbyiJaUPSMu1atBklNOHrervwFsmZkLUs8BRda5NqsUuqxACLr0xxCr7exvlXTIssWpwyp8U9VeBayj4-sOcepYmxJ84-p-lFgKFmVDO7zjNwLo0EXidauKh2IeiV-LyPKcu7qGFm8ywHWb4493ttde35vSfJm08mEAOgAGdo39n70=>  More context: remember this AdExchanger round-up from 2009 on the impact of Right Media Exchange (read #1 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnudueb838cvM0hw3vdhtimCn6PLo8LrM7fDvFYT_iN2DmK1nOySMrEMfxe8GItZ0vHs1xEOw4QoG-zQPu3hmbqkrGgxB1BD7PBvQHqPV_XRp_45rO4mYAkeKPrL7GZS6q_aoDCnhDCrNxuo-R-0X5pbZtcA7s2wh4orP7WW_BfldZQ90I_XGC_I3a_3vd26FHSf3s=> , #2 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnududMrsNWe4yTiTL24sfAGpesEDRdt7DQTX8IamjVFIuat5zqbg03jYKfTrr0jyVXerycCTNzNxU-hH41gE9o_PL_4hWb9Gmrg0FMXTrH4QjbUWYrl0EWoPkEddA4mV3DP2d-gz7LY0D9fTa_9VVuApJ7Q5y9AlEwSFBGx92CIB7qF7QVdL-W1IxiUiUf629GxGA42wheTKQz_w==> , #3 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnuducqxjrzptV2pRntJt8rlQV5shw3T2OHA-cpWeak_lz8S2DpOltDGMfwhpf1zUwrr65V7R66fMIeXeSRm_4bcrCiSemkRgNGAcQ0sD8FEQ03q9IgReJ-rXWnOJVictd6_lvgk5wBTqFSL4eMKpFddtBBHWoIZK2XvDgsxwjeLMKIiTNGLxJZyjn_fZNsv_3ybDGHYBrJ2x9rlQ==> , #4 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnuducLxZZ6YF0AHr8b8zynaZEzbE3S-hjY6tBaoL177wAWTdfB4x9IW4yOSdXqA9bvwDxQ7fnynElfPD2ME_2zHOd1TgcL0NsEgfuw2eJanIHWAd-7HPrSJVDsxIApqXvL1foybsHy6skD5QUJ16F4O8dA2RPVyQ8PQ5KK2ZmtCgD93_YFjJyEfZHLh52iUZe_taV1XS6GAE5QGg==> )? Even today, part of the frustration with RMX stems from the industry's own desire for competition in the exchange space while Google continues to innovate, or acquire, at a breakneck pace. Given Facebook Exchange's growth in such a short time, maybe there's possibility of a Yahoo-FBX tie-up down the road using FBX's newer "pipes"? It could be a powerful programmatic "cocktail" if the partnership could include shared addressability via Yahoo Mail and Facebook Custom Audiences. Let alone those Tumblr log-ins.

 

Facebook Ad Momentum

 

Facebook releases its Q2 2013 results Wednesday afternoon <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnudue52c9B2NR_z73m2avY_T_UcHj-ADrWHgiL_1WbgjNu8ti280eSxQeM2Fiz5apqYKvPTr4NQ9pBv1DQmuMvbmqVFuEoiOZndG09HrjkLUL88ArfTyP5VYUvVpzCpOFioMfd8BD1gL-kPR5vJt6ZBy_K>  and JP Morgan analyst Doug Anmuth sees ad momentum coming in the second half of the year "to be driven by improved and simplified ad formats, continued progress with News Feed ads, FBX in the News Feed, and video ads." He adds, "We believe better targetability should lead to ROI improvements and higher advertiser demand. As we've indicated in previous notes, we believe advertiser quality improved in 2Q with more large brand marketers on the site."

 

Email As Ads

 

Ads in Gmail are nothing new, but according to VentureBeat, Google has changed things up a bit by introducing ads that look like emails. A statement from the company says that ads will only appear in users' promotions tab AND will only appear when they are completely relevant AND can be dismissed easily AND the ads always appear at the top of the inbox AND they are clearly labeled. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnududYCtoEJhpFCRoVrvHrrgq8qYAJDx6EZV2sIFuDkDTuYBm_GDzpFVF6RfWpB9bfB9twN7a8pmIIFiWlW7yJ8Y7uxc26A1WdFRIKM3b-YErRoE9EbMIbh--X1C3tP8vJttv0OnC2NNvYNcGeAVenWQYewb72Y6Mw1yw=> .

 

Educating Wall Street

 

Ad tech firms can sell ads, but can they sell themselves? Ad Age's Tim Peterson explores the problem public companies such as Tremor Video, Millennial Media and Marin are facing with less than stellar stock prices. He finds a lack of knowledge from Wall Street investors, companies that are pushed into going public because venture capitalists need out or, hey, they just don't want to invest in the first place, OK? Both Marin's and Tremor's CEOs noted that educating investors is a top priority. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnudue-8NrmioF2I3muRzmukYAuwiWjSexrHbyUUG88Y0YRAV1rzBctMtuOd_r3JF4HZEM9aJ1BbXE3HJtIkYiadRK1R2cERzLzvbQqzD236eskI7gaT-I6CWn7H33Rp7wBO2DKwYvuCqB6ceb0Hj6s-tRM1GjB09zsBM-X1fwEaOrZspUOhFttilPrhViutauvY6Q=> .

 

Differentiating Video

 

Jefferies analyst Brian Pitz recommended Tremor Video stock to his firm's clients yesterday. His Tremor analysis: "Unlike most peers, Tremor has access to exclusive high quality content through tier-1 partnerships with A&E, Viacom, and others. As of 1Q13, Tremor had ~200 out of 500 premium websites and mobile applications partnerships on an exclusive basis, which gives the company a competitive advantage. Tremor fills the white space between Youtube's reach and Hulu's brand affinity, providing advertisers with access to premium content, as an exclusive 'premium publisher', and wide audience reach."

Make It Count

 

kbs+p's Darren Herman dishes out some best practices for agencies and vendors in a column for Digiday. Some of his points include only taking relevant meetings, being on time and being prepared. Although his tips are tailored for sales meetings, they do seem applicable for most professions. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnuduf511go_aoK2Few-bLZ737W4TjKJFateCEtnBJfWy7qBJe0TJ001Xvxn4vRxS4XogL6qdSc6PFFN_NwiNOQg0nhxdqFHk-vZ1l8CeCLo_Cilcb6cMe_tCVjnDVZisNl7Q7fdx2ygRrZRAeGwtXbFBuctM6umV2r1uLYc8bQJuwtlg==> .

 

Optimizing Shopping

 

South Korean home shopping network, NS Shopping, has chosen IBM to handle its data, user experience, mobile and more, according to a press release. By utilizing a suite of IBM technologies, the company seeks to improve its digital presence as dictated by changing consumer habits. From the release, "The enterprise-wide transformation with analytics and ecommerce technology from IBM's Smarter Commerce initiative enables NS Shopping to uncover data insights about individual consumer preferences while developing mobile applications to deliver a consistent, connected customer experience across multiple devices." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0018cYzVtnudueo-Z8wmeUrTH3TAe9eSRT3kh6u5YvwyDnZlCGPotURvCY6TChyZqWFIo0V_cGJcPesxflFfm23YBHubmISGFkubpc3lUm1Ez4oZy90zU9AIgidP-YXwzSYtsXNuvUTYCr1y5SHoQRhwqcIrTI9abeO4xVjdC6Vwl0=> . Next stop, media.

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>   

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35YklpTaEUemXOSa7asK4EMbATXmM9EaJZhkQcBch_r3zwvqy6-7062zvTNTVPoEyq9ZqNtv6zujtOrBA5Jg-lSuaBQX2AP1mIXZCk1jSkPjWxuAInu5s0jZRTI7GwzPHBQez8=> .

 

Local Apples

 

Apple has been busy during the weekend as news broke that they've picked up a couple of companies on the "local" front. All Things D reported early on Friday that Toronto-based crowdsourced location data company Locationary is now part of the fold. Read about it <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35Yklo1hlP3K1TwpbkpnRlRFIrOr8zk2zSMPn4h98vRS6GkIyM8ippdemg3bNy8VGRkpvjNmhhSiSo3XG0n0jT8u1NfrZInFZbshdN40SgLrmff8Hwduf8pXPDfwT8KwEoPXPoEJR_H1GZLhh1UMHEYqbdiMpjFihm9ZSbpHxKB0lauZpc7QzJ8oTF_> . On Saturday, Bloomberg reported that online transit navigation service HopSpot has been scooped up, too. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35Ykloua8xUxzEto8dNI_6QqSy1fB1eSkERsmTRs9jOUIciX7_oHJ2sqUk7Rb4k9T5BFhJF81lkBEg-Kb3pwjGgauhslez5PbJU_zcaHbJij1xchs5BYoyUCwqAh7n6w6GCrNUFJlGS7uEO5-hPSnM6xFf8DxJEoBKQQ--v7oOlORgRq6RFFrBJrITT3rrrKMPfmWIki1hUtQWRMPiyD271JIln> . Location data may be the new cookie - whether you're addressing the consumer with ads or content - or a devilish, native mix.

 

The End Of Advertising

 

In a rebuke of direct marketing and, perhaps inadvertently, part of his company's own business model, LinkedIn co-founder Allen Blue tells Forbes' Adam Tanner that direct marketing is on the way out: "Going back to 'Mad Men,' going back to 1950s, so much of that was a whole bunch of people who were essentially ignorant of the opportunities that existed in the world around them. Advertising is a distribution mechanism to get the word out. That's not the world we live in anymore." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35Yklpo26UXno8gp0owD_el4HI5F4wfjdhtNIpCNWhy6MvwgUmkI-kBVB8N-nUGyl0QGApxvwWlBUBQYLyNtMEo63Kikigo67N55AMTBnqBznxtF9Pz_qYEaiq-L73qPYOzJh9PI7JlxUkX5SrZJnDPRDCqoVP4UfUEdW6h9zkrJZybfG8WYeSyhNicvx1Xz2blvB1i9zQFMyIEavDk76ahYSB6SFOlQuKP-gd_mXoSfH16vtYc4VKRC35a> . That could be difficult positioning for a growing media company <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35YklpmDFcaj6Y5JaN-yjjxV1M9KAtsKj3cp1b259OaWeAB7cwSE2yyVvhBDIqtZsY8hqRsgpOkVPUZvjJPs5wwYn_MTC_-xuyCOTzaFtzxxihoZYuoQ6nfS8P3g_Stszz-dyVEqrrIPtmN6XxQLtznHMUuK2Zk-PlA9vnwEYeOALfiSg==> .

 

Connecting To TV

 

In advance of its IPO, YuMe is continuing to make connected TV deals as it did with Samsung Electronics (2012 press release <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35Yklp_FJAETwvphlfusdypL3X7VGiJHG4w6nz84qNcjHOVx9WSbh3OOovM-nEPeuuZvjOuIvVmwYIFpwrUJ_NpkQiAqiIB1eqHcDUJJmd1uY1ZmYkERYU5nAJxCfPNxvDddge7FucxQ_Gg30jDIXTiJdJ9U4heBulOS0zrvIPM35JGJwoGPlkvSDxU7ou8Lmip8iQ82nPkQj7qGKtIfreHzCA9MxSGsUp5c1kjGh--Hgn1frsH2KGjbdHN> ) and LG (2011 interview <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35YklrQfK9y4RI0oCK3kKGvluCPyak86ADft_pF-l5Xz2TBTTaTEj8UrE2fsunN6ckaVNE9LyB2IVRWBmGnFsFxhS6NKyrIOcF1RZh8ooYIOdfFUKmmvYFO0lTQaRAuNmLgNbJ2eDLs6zonpg==> ). This time the deal is with a music video app provider called VidZone. What's that? From the release: "VidZone launched successfully in Europe in 2009, [and] has been downloaded by more than 7.5 million PS3 users and has delivered over 3 billion ad impressions." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35YklrNtmaIM6mqlMKiy7ei60BJTZQGng4NqTXkuEX5jLi8-d--LzEBdpb1J9d9OBoRdM-4ONL2FPk1L_3XW6GJuxUqlmdZc2RHjBRjhEt4oBew3TK0PZUNxMOVsEbzI3qyS7LDNlDxX1lyZeo7RnZQF1NTfjoH2UZv4ISthHGm7WLvut6iQB7r6vsQR_eX0j3p4IV8GdP6pt0yMlSMAxlyK17Hx5mkqk_Q-Zw=> . YuMe's strategic investor is connected, too - Samsung Ventures <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35Yklovw8e4CwmEHsX45dBoCaVri3YadnAvx6kcweWoDvkL27bCwR1XCr9glzOhsNJWyyV94yKOnfIhZDchNNtyrYrLneMxsqFmaVNG_jdubu7QvWA6ECu-Edne28FJmnw9MkQ1-P1FWJ77UiAftwLz_7M5DAVEa0VGTsuXzrpPOtpkSw==> .

 

India's Ad Problems

 

India is a huge market for advertising, but a lot of companies prefer to stick to tried and true methods rather than getting "creative," according to ClickZ. Prabhvir Sahmey lays out six reasons advertising is still behind in India, including lack of understanding of scalability and "dots not being connected." Sahmey writes, "Success in RTB depends on consolidation, data management, creative management, as well as audience measurement. All of these are enabled using technology." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35Yklpu-BgGOxNqkULBenSnwIsfD_xgDBLCog08j1c3WjM4RoOiNEdnnDNWyz9NN63BvHppW0NeEiMqfx4oIkA2fFzcOMVtg_9LOmmIkOPSrdmKmGG7M_aUEIhXiq1UYcrtSlDy-SwebnAqi-RPsaUhsl8EJGIFvh5dIJE6iknpEH7UzZoODUbk1-h3> .

 

Mobile Privacy

 

The Commerce Department released a mobile privacy proposal that would require app developers to inform consumers, in short-form, of what data is collected and why. This method, according to MediaPost's Wendy Davis, is problematic because the terms are ambiguous in many cases. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35YklovH9hES_KDx8yy6tEA1uAL6QZlYH7Qtn8lXab3NTnRReOXQICSrbf7bacHXtVz7ceh97dHpIhDqx_d7BxuUnLFyjnpnXUmD_U8FpgAyYKr7wYZwsWkO7T_pSdDV1ctaoQnHVO1vM4W1qihku18dTYMHEvZYsjv8fvhpzFTobjbcIUE_G9mkIYyeGcavydtUdJmD-Tsh84rgUDDw_zlwy990hLu1_ju2lMPxaHCy42OjJ6NVTlNwZfu> .

Reaching For Agency Biz

 

comScore publicly released its pay-for-play ad network numbers for the month of June on Friday. It's interesting to note that retargeter Criteo, which comes in 7th by reach in the U.S. according to comScore, has decided to "pony up" the fee. This could signal increased focus on agency business which this list attempts to target - especially as Criteo's prez Greg Coleman pushes toward brand business and moving up-funnel. See the comScore release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35Yklp_pa98qhyMV4vDs6oNUsDLMQg2mjFP0wgR2UqBZPR2EEeYS6iGAa9Xm-JsZNhmrwiUBlPfVcEOnhu1aFnwlc-7fJnaJRAbQprkT6bWmWIj9LXImNaFwK65M3lbfAgS9zLl8q3c74Fk-aMypIZDujsTBSFmmRvOVlOQ-22IzQXGXu1a_L929WG-McRbTiXOCI4PCNVDeXoUH3RVhxNRnXjzK0C_RH3LiAaQ-yifNeGk9sIHe74Idlhnq4irzxJg0aM=>  When/if Criteo goes public (in the fall?), they're going to be looking for "easy" areas of expansion to feed the bottom line.

 

Consolidation For Whom?

 

Tech consolidation is looming, and Eric Franchi, co-founder of Undertone, believes agencies will be the driving force, which he details in a post for Ad Age. Part of his reasoning is that agency budgets are keeping the ecosystem thriving and eventually these agencies are going to consolidate vendors, leaving a lot of smaller players behind. Furthermore, the talk of brands delaying payments would be disaster for smaller operations. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=0010kMpk35Yklq0wR9GHcwlOsZzBdaxFx6WweRp5jGNclWH6xRUDrmKq43AOpnKB7vd6uDqCXx9RgulRbnAmXWy8M9cmliBPUXzFa2iKrz0c99MRqD65RmEtKFwJ04Ij-fCJ2PsA5WqFupR8rMoZiUlZO6sSc8oaz0V8JSc1nCCMmrnuKgy24wBStTVcVomOmk9YNwGw0SI_b-7PMmfFMHRlA==> .

Retargeting Co-op

 

Fetchback's former CEO, Chad Little, is back for more. Faithful readers know that display-ad retargeter Fetchback was acquired by GSI Commerce in 2010 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BAccrM75BpTzdzehJ2jmuNoD635-qBH6WWwnpPLNOF-r3PAbaJbPkgfNtoC2e56C0AIZ7-jxNo9kZ3ezZ8jLIRukM2KiFnuPOj3PzOWIpmPAuPWjYhaeV9sSMGeFu6Zo8TekgszUNLU22a2iOh3eN6ZzcGMeYkZg_U=>  (for a rumored $40 million or so) -- and then GSI was acquired by eBay in 2011 <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BD82IkjBlOwG3Tpav40ZJZYYHgRLCLW5dZsBptwEot6-azDLsJUedovHXPpT8b3xLm6mB0w0rhkY9Xohm0eLZVdVsXsvW4PAau5yb6vWF_zUBHvEi5_-m07oaZRb5JXy96iYncE0x13FZ5YIxck6E2fjyoXoGbV66DJFxlg72VT-A==> . Little moved on to his next entrepreneurial endeavor along the way and has announced that his new company, Adhesive.co, has raised $1.5 million. According to a press release, he's launching a retargeting co-op (sounds a bit like Adroit's strategy <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BAJKf4rbZpuukpXCF0sNHHRUexoc4T7mIcVamy6x2c8JIww7IUuBMwPoQvwo2YOx5J5OyILk6XLghB9ld-yWI7E3han0MFmny2OQTqY7rBnrc-QlgrFI98D>  courtesy of Akamai's pixel-free tech) and advertisers who participate can purchase retargeting campaigns at a $0.50 CPM rate. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BB9xxP9iF4Cn-UIISE6cduv1M2Ar73v0DkYN-svSGzYfCYU42RHAFNRxpao6AU30mnwC-P8SU_H4GXRRUFUtj-O2VF7j9tmKQrbfF8bySX2PHvYsDFR7xkWGHsfxONK9egEw1Nln1CB0WySX-CWFeMhM7hJzuOByCu5qBTV14wrdE9Gc3tou1ona9YKfy9aGIywPWC7XJUmqRiNdwX3nknkDEASCjluSH3gFojlHTr8ycp_acQFOO7G> .

 

Good Consumers, Bad Data

 

Speaking of Adroit, a new Adroit study shows that the group most resistant to being retargeted based on "old" data is educated and wealthy consumers. "This survey confirms for us the importance of using fresh data for all kinds of ad targeting," says Adroit Digital General Manager Scott German. He discusses another finding about consumers: "While we're pleased to see that the overwhelming majority of consumers do not mind being retargeted - and a large number even enjoy it - this survey demonstrates the risks that can come from hitting the same consumer for too long and failing to apply data insights to campaigns to improve performance." Read the study here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BAxUR3aLxuHWvtYMLM_X_Xut4m5HhHLreVe8SpTWiRgP5JdKFQEMimv8lsrtRiO3b5hkVt_0LMBrmD6dgXdWhGFcTnRGzfkkphY-z6hMusKMscRi93haz77THvI237jMKbBv9oPklq-yyawuSiNFIBd2L-ozmlDXmu4vjc5jj-oFg==> , and the press release here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BC5ZW6r2aawqqTb5sxZK8b2ZXScLNE4fJbP8X_UNYVwiFXERNxKHzDLzMA_KG900cowIw6XTCBfYjYVfEMsufCCpEwEF9QygyCNDGI8GFCZ83lG_sYtuCyXLkfy6PfE1MPSkvgl385KDZHZVK_31yM1uBrSSv-CXCA=> .

 

Mobile Is Hard

 

Mobile advertising can't be treated like desktop advertising, which Victor Malachard of Adfonic explores in a column for VentureBeat. There are not only technological differences (cookies, screen size), but user behavior is different as well. He writes, "The means by which you reach those audiences are going to be different, and for mobile this means deep expertise in how mobile works. We simply do not believe that online specialists understand the complexity and nuances of mobile." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BBLkW4LsI3baT3--ygg4rRgqZWzecZMnekPauCThXLIouBb-Mp_nEjREte8ANWsznVPovFIFZsf0qQcpg0onbR2yeYlyybQ99jccxIe6x1xxtBdIdjR-YPWSZsUnbroQqKKAB0FvB60-5ZWsP39PFB1rsLofq1rLRBAPAyNxu0vuvvS7eGAhAKo_O2kW39vRYo=> .

 

Free Please

 

People don't like ads, but what they really don't like is paying for content. Flurry analyzed the app trend and discovered there has been an increase in free apps due to low demand for paid ones. While iOS users are more likely to pay for apps, it's still not enough users to stop the trend of free apps with ads. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BDTO8NXQhkvqfH8TLcDuud_MTpaLl_fWNV1ytpFdzHKSKD0-3rJKg0jUU2HK_li-jhRuJyNk-P_55lZBM9Et8H9qQB_MPGTPiQ7ziqY9rVi9K2li_lYsS1ni3i4tWRxh_sjqVZ425oYs9WTclNTbakiyZAZLav2XYstgk-edUsiI7PzPwCOvPAvKojlwAIbKbnLiAG3sL8Bkw==> .

 

Unlockable Money

 

New startup Locket is hoping Android users are willing to let their lock screen be taken over by an ad for a small reward. The company, which has raised $500,000, is launching its app in beta today, according to TechCrunch. "What we're trying to do is change the perception people have toward ads. On mobile, ads suck right now," says Kim. "But our ads are different because they're beautiful and they actually reward you for your glances. We hope users will like it." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BB1p8XYkNT8Mdoh7kdR-_Ks-AWDaZOHrM7EtdJWiH_hMy071_OR_fiC8VbKRzTKQu1fxNJ8fWZd7Icle2OW8WjHj2V6DaAcDiFYwHDh8jhSr21h46TnleEiqasNFklHF1yUBR_UN0v1dfsGEmv-X3tkxBVe9QtVXQKeHsOvUS1w0oWLs1dcgzL3SvnMkgQhJx1aYnzAZ9TQeLwm5yuEBwpYFuoe5Q6EELI=> .

Can TV Go Both Ways?

 

Online video is a huge trend right now, but what happens to TV as online begins to dominate? Dave Morgan of Simulmedia looks at the TV-to-Web trend in a MediaPost column to answer that question. If TV providers are smart, he writes, they will innovate to keep up with the trends by doing things like offering on-demand capabilities on the Web that rival companies like Netflix and Hulu. Another advantage these companies have are complementary shows and ads, as well as networks, which really attract big advertising dollars because of the relatively stable ROI. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001YN_KHcJN-BCco3qVcZ9naW7r7VXjmrAyeJB_a77VGo_CdoEaWaP7kjmLZ-khsyJOt3tOo6hJCWgHYHFqChChsmFpAZgYDI0Tm-hUS8Nsx0C6cCE64lCDYx3MgJ7OKLzrQnqSOoHjgztCER3PdbrkwKZGjtGQFvziHsisM4xVzGJejQ7R4HPUqs8zn8m1vGrwxC_yof25Y5Fo5WfuRQEHMaZii-O6mw4U5rw2tPWdBm9m7kEQaXUN7qPY7hIQ50kS> .

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>   

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei095csWcHQ9pIzwuA5xnvJrsDUriei7nMmNr4mVhmysUoYcgHmJqhatINbmVswTbydMYotR2fawNrMT8L9FkG-daS2b_H4ML5vSeBhUmxI128gFBrZ8tu4XDHUBsG0jrefss=> .

 

RTB Inventory Flat

 

Growth has slowed for exchange-traded media, according to a report released by Accordant Media, but media quality has increased. "Q2 turned out to be a notable period for (the) programmatic media industry," said Art Muldoon, Accordant Media's co-founder and CEO, in a release. "The headlines shifted from hyper growth of RTB volume to how buyers are assessing and scaling a broad range of innovative targeting tactics that create value for advertisers." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei0956J1oApn-ERlG08qDp03u-0cQiDtJpxeKWz0IA-YNUVM1KqfY5qLGIgzlJR_A-BjLsZVY5aVpCNhLPC1EM6PeeoGcB4kmhY-ATeemlsGBGAhLO5y2VoT_gxgzxMQSEiV_bE1Nh26ZOUcqHdrewxYXu0oXFzqQ5v8bhS9XePhty4iclIm0RWTQFX-KJogwgaOt_g41b40U3qMxdTxaVop2XK9dXpb8Dxm7zHOQRkrycU9o-FtUFXi6aold_-wThs8p8Hmp6-7_TSqvSD1sBIissN913Oa8PejjCvKqL2LcW-gvd1yjBLN8S> . One finding: "Global volume growth of RTB ad inventory was flat in Q2 over Q1, although still up 28% vs. the prior year quarter." The "flatness" echoes a similar report by Rubicon Project recently. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei096G6Ws-EVx_ltVFotTt2HXSdfGDzpGnM23fTzTyb_TKhs_9h4VM1Vg9Ivkilo5BtlsWfPBepvxE5Ysm8SWYRue3Z7AC3bXBXOJTgPXghtTtLCQcvTdGAqEm9LsKxhEIZ6dUNE44xbqmjz_3zr5YTnQihgqHNpLX0V6jOrK0Gr2SncOd186NXh0bODY__caWmcHPNb1qBwek4nIINUiTk8XYLMsPxeQ60Hs=>  Meanwhile, mobile exchange and ad server MoPub sees more "demand participation in RTB" for its growing mobile exchange. See the Slideshare prezo. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei094wjdwkZLDbASzEd7Cy-V7MYMiOtwFvzkr2N7KjWIuJb7SlEAjKrR8O4h7gA2Z-pbTyWmOrUn4Hv4skXldV15MpXt_RXoNxyLQzrq74v5_lBo5JkQkCbp7qdjgv_zAqCx9iTvhLbpd7LpROAThLkt5PjUDOdtfGPnq4Kit4FuAO8w==> 

 

More Mobile

 

Another day, another mobile acquisition. Data-management platform [x+1] announced its acquisition of mobile-marketing firm WDA through a press release. "Mobile is critical to our clients," said John Nardone, [x+1]'s chief executive officer, "and it's only becoming more so as time goes on. Meeting the full range of their needs was important to us; and this led us to WDA." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei095jZzBYCAQBIzJC3Ba9Ukb3Wjs6FL77TLBQPJhaXp6D6Dy-NeKFjrx82Y95F-M9xZKav1PCvdzdQ6HWqAZCniDdsf28hBJPMeHaMnfQaxXV7i2wsqidXUWDggEFv6z9BPxbrJg5DJQ34PX9aeMbAFrW> .

 

RTB Trading Soars

 

Nexage announced that RTB-traded inventory accounts for 50% of money flowing through its exchange. The company's CMO, Victor Milligan, spoke to MediaPost, saying he doesn't think RTB is cannibalizing mediated trading, but RTB continues to grow rapidly. "We expected to have fast growth," Milligan said, "but I think it's fair to say this has exceeded expectations." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei0953k40RHYkdPkBkhaYngnT0Vyi1LcWmmKP15-jaXZ2A_OlDziTVVhleB26L9BuKW3n3xjmM0shPXX3pNpYebLp4UIQz5kdem4ahaPTTXR3Nby5IMUYD6QPuzb1WdE0B5ron0lYq6k0wADYXJnBGQTTpR4g89opRHTeIzOnMLFIeG6_tzP6Kgbr70zStMPHE1MrI3ucMMzPrISZgdvWTYc7skI2ptCYmuc8s9EygKxaM3-HDcUMGU5bn> .

 

Latency Solutions



Site latency is an issue, and mismanagement of tags contributes to that problem, according to an Evidon blog post. If pages are loading slowly, users click away before any data is collected, so Evidon recommends optimization as a solution. "Strategic deployment of tag managers and CDNs allow tags to load synchronously, mitigating the impact on total page time. Site technology can also be configured so that certain tags only fire when they're most useful, and well-managed exchange relationships can maximize return from fewer deployed marketing partners." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei096jTUmcefO1KICOEBFjjHZsmi_RGCE5Ep71kerod2yAmvkMViv0VMuqaHI-eWGqp5jk--HTrr0jUh3d9EW__lVHQ4wLVLUKeo7r-BUaaVrgRmHKPlMWYsRzQKByZ7riebozAIMQZMCWyA==> .

 

Relevant Funding

 

Under-the-radar Context Relevant, which has been working with several large Web publishers, among others, has raised venture funding. Read more about it on TechCrunch <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei0941hY_fGA99Gffju_R6Rpc8P_giur-RjqtR9u-9x_rXP0BVluk5jDPNqygRkteGhrxcMUuTYUwgFIiN03jqwulKuQkbHWpkoPnS7cj3abuQCCo4tcVu974u2d3scKz29XzU8cJQLGZXF_wzzeOlpSr636E9fIJEAEgvplL-rfDIWBp11wv2WEqKifAGhQBvtEw=> , which explains, "Context Relevant uses real-time data from HDFS, SQL, web logs, CRM systems, market data and social media to output analyses and projections on how a business might be impacted in the future." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei0941hY_fGA99Gffju_R6Rpc8P_giur-RjqtR9u-9x_rXP0BVluk5jDPNqygRkteGhrxcMUuTYUwgFIiN03jqwulKuQkbHWpkoPnS7cj3abuQCCo4tcVu974u2d3scKz29XzU8cJQLGZXF_wzzeOlpSr636E9fIJEAEgvplL-rfDIWBp11wv2WEqKifAGhQBvtEw=> .

No Cookie Means Creative

 

Dan Schwartz, co-founder of ad platform Run, says the lack of cookie targeting that inhibits effective real-time bidding in mobile compared to desktop may be a good thing. He tells Mobile Marketer, "Brands should be aware of the fact that unlike in the desktop world, mobile is not predisposed to the commoditization impact that is now so prevalent in the desktop world. Because of the lack of a persistent cookie in mobile, true creativity is required in order to target at scale." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei096lbyCzlL6JVT62aCD2nNJluF0jMtqEplJYySMR0G5_107s2t7S65MDxBOzD_urn9WGmFt6KKwemJvvmMZMG1uBrui9BuUvKd8Kyel5ol9eb2vMr7UA93BN4_L3iclOJT86ZUfU8g2xulbbiEkIdJGeaUnoP-c-lDaT9yL27lWRoA==> .

 

Ad Tech Isn't The Only Tech

 

Ad spend in the technology industry soared in Q1, with the biggest players being Intuit and Microsoft, according to Nielsen. Intuit, maker of personal financial software, generally spends a lot in Q1 because of taxes, but this year Microsoft knocked the company from its No. 1 spot. A possible reason technology ad spend is so high could be that as people become more comfortable with technology, the advertising potential to grab new customers expands. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei095FdjjMjTpjKR6eUGbhA4gGaWrTil2j2pejVSCJDKonp8xQ91uof9pkk4JstBOI0Q0luqU1uF0dGGoxEImmKeCEE5kbTNDoLIpISleGfCF0CeckXOuMxSx_h29ZPjYqw1E9oUQYYV95XeiY8xMaF-cb7J0i_p9IQN9-7eRrrr83UB0oYV1UV_Ia-sM8UwCi1mtd2UiLJSKXqWVu6Pa9l0Ud> .

 

Microsoft Taps comScore

 

Microsoft Advertising announced it will begin using comScore's validated Campaign Essentials for its digital ad inventory. "Microsoft already provides a compelling platform for marketers. By utilizing vCE's audience, viewability and brand safety features, it can significantly improve the delivery of campaigns (...)," said Serge Matta, President of comScore in a press release. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001Saw02gei096Xxih7ZRukWMp9UIljvVxo18B39Owk07mlHRy1XY348rSCbpxCW51KL_AqY525X2oHjtCLdmdPC5sIPy4R-uZPg7zml5d58QM_MvdE8YEweyB_DzhHcb_DZ_i7iacfjddtL8_MMyPs5LAGKLs7wE6XtSCWUj4Ntlsw14F3clrTrrioA1cMDBHGHUL5dOHm3zhgS8cv-mpcIFxCb-c2zJVJNVzq3i-rxYfb-YsvoS_CZRg1L1dhRotdpiEdbpnIz3i5ODBANGo7JA==> .

 News Round-Up <http://ih.constantcontact.com/fs116/1102602719219/img/94.jpg>   

Here's today's AdExchanger news round-up... Want it by email?
Sign-up here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3khieWoQ0dGsiSLsL6KNstQ36ieBBbaxxp7ABg-lHS03obiJRgcY3-HuscJ1M_nxHqFw7bcweyviriI3_UuqC3J2ZZ-_2QlHzQ2XTfcjkq0-c1t1mybQuw-sjSikChBQ-LU=> .

 

Media6Degrees Targets Mobile

 

Media6Degrees made its mobile play yesterday by acquiring Everyscreen Media, according to Ad Age. "All the data we get from Web browsers is about to be doubled or tripled," said CEO Tom Phillips as he referenced users moving to a multidevice world that includes smartphones, tablets and desktop computers. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3ki1rQGjbwCfQ_I2G51HVVQv0T6US7GArZH8O38XpMTZ5oi7fVE0u04_6dIdsIyq44vwt4t6VfTClKvBX8yhuQeOKlpffdZm-e7TkqW0862jx7Rq9ttCCNADOzisU78MYYw4YBOAVyeu1dOiBceEdhdNfNj-Wr9cHVM75EEweOaab3ZrY-oYqBvVkRK8WTAtWO_eT0H0Jvv__Bl8fE3CIrmv> . Everyscreen has 12 people and will help bring exchange buying to the mobile channel for Media6Degrees as it augments its cross-screen/cross-channel pitch. Read the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3kgT0vfeEu2qm2bAvGF1-f_6-wGfi-ZOXBi0XhYhO4kLwl7_KvTV3DTRKSQBBUCfGewlGaPOpoPPx2bGkE4NbYhh5exfut7QBOhOh35GSS0j25SdyUy2jSzOVHY_LjqpfYlUrRxA3Mg2rlpQoFcuAlH9Pt3tQKNmRtDMl9Vlmg2I3VQHKOjzfbF8LOSUAIbD0CQpEkOz31tsWPiKRLr-6V303NK-QCinF84=>  And, read AdExchanger's interview with Everyscreen earlier this month. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3khM5mpgQo1Z5itjfLIq6t1vWcyBOsBRVsH0iqaY0bkWbcAj8bZy_PbgQs-Z4HBReBYeoX08DPwif9DyFv5Ba56Y27o2Q5PpSBdCM2LLIZrSx-YjWtSaQQ1ahnUNW7eiRRrm5-2iDzl3i_a2d_Wv6cSJ-6qoMNvXhJHtMN2qKkuR3Jws4Cy3bNSlyP9_69OPz-l1ZymR8fKVJkDMuEGZMBg9eam8JeUAAMk=> 

 

Stickerbook

 

Facebook may be losing its cool factor, but the company continues to innovate in hopes of holding onto its youthful audience. PC World's Caitlin McGarry examines Facebook's sticker product, which could be what the social network needs to recapture its younger users. As of right now, Facebook doesn't charge for the use of stickers, but if gets more eyeballs on the site it will attract advertiser dollars. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3kiiRin_OJqo6j3591gk-9Zr6yiAV9k6uFEK2QPvP0z758SaXAb_lw8iUFWIiMxIH-pdiEhWnW7UmXRFsLhS_jGhC7ojhs4C7DIyPPeKPK9dDT36tuimyTf5EaDkTBbIEJWHBEscNRzuMynLvAtlZinvou-VHiBqanJGRXMDSNBxjawsFRhnBGTgWCcAC0VhBOk9_YB_sHMLGg==> .

 

DAA Proposal Shot Down

 

Leaders of the Tracking Protection Working Group rejected proposed standards submitted by the DAA, according to CNET. Alex Fowler, chief privacy officer at Firefox, said, "Mozilla is pleased with the W3C co-chairs' decision to use the June Draft as the basis for the Do Not Track standard, and for recognizing that the DAA's alternate proposal would have been a step backwards in user choice and privacy." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3kgNggF-epwU16QNEvMzBsFXbAmcTxf6gN1FO9MzXVaUJITXFugxsN14Q5r6cPxP_Ga4znI7DNpcjoKU_Sf1Fy1Bua3lzuycrpnw6iccY12RcWP2ik6XPIjr-dB-dCwklCmaZk8SED3f2_ptNDZfalwbXneS0PInnkYP5isG7ch5Uj8z-ksaldwfEi-58ipTVb05_rkW8iAdEY4O9yEoz4RRf0upRq4sHcs=> . IAB CEO and President Randall Rothenberg, who pulled no punches in a recent AdExchanger interview <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3khpgK55MgpoXwznUfZxfaWCP6aU2D_-vDN64BS4wRROeTK721EUCBWSKnuFSZ3YBScU-aO17vVjygehRw77-jbL__4WdbiAEl_pMrtbWCHwrmU-yD68rrxRWr2mLTbRYdKHHxJB9gJ2ltrCVE4RHaZiqfen9TNKSVQ=> , took to the IAB's blog to condemn the decision. Read that one <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3khMX3lVe5joYw5Xm6BpddWoB0EvNVYsEW-WVUefxobO0AxLEXJS1h3oxxRYfDa2fR7vjxD4T0r7C_VYbQPuDAbUGkIkErA14VTAShmNctzLqdOdHDOJFml1cSYj2owOLEjRmGX61reyyrP3FjNLS8nk899OoBL0MBcPRVX5nUEwhw==> .

 

Reducing Ad Tech Tax

 

Seth Demsey, SVP of global advertising products and strategy at AOL, examined the inefficiencies in the online advertising industry in a column for Digiday. As he puts it, "A market where $1 is really only worth $.45 cannot sustain itself." His proposed solution is to focus more on creating an open ecosystem around innovation rather than dozens of niche products. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3kiL-XOEWMVpHzXQ_svrwr608wLViOh-h9zZgId_YUeO_6LGpM7XFIcgkDXMNo62Rsflb-r6XANaao6sWsF923SNXELwbItyoieAj5Gy96F9x2GuMBxLFlroRPmuWK3FN56ZTodjuD0Yoqcvqy_-K-jJ4RVyiyCVO8NorVZwYPDpKg==> .

 

Big Video

 

Online video advertising has received a lot of attention lately, and this time it's from Coady Diemar Partners, an investment banking company. The takeaway from their aggregation of video facts and figures is that online video viewing habits are much different than traditional TV viewing (short-form vs. long-form), so advertising dollars should be spent based on the strengths of each. Read what those may be <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3kjEjDf-G4hklk4jEhfgUA3Td6I8Yx3JS5ddQChqNeSZMypK3bNUy1PNpA2geN_1jfwhzT7lUOnwetaLxD8zOVLM6kbdnjF37sneWF1CLAJORoHz29KubS8S-uSI9ALbNfxNfl6QqS5RVnyBdaIM83qz> .

Loyal Dessert 

 

Three hot trends have converged: frozen yogurt, mobile apps and loyalty programs. According to Mobile Commerce Daily, fro-yo giant Pinkberry is encouraging members of its loyalty program to download the company's app, which lets users track their rewards, gift cards and purchases. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3khx0qS7B2qxGhdCh3WsGnYyro_neSd1rfQ3_LUghAzrfQNZQXjgTqxcHnLP-bzq-nbcWdVPmv51gTMbJRKSGsoQ6ID9vQiMW_ZwKf1RoEaO6yGTL4WK8XuN8xAzwmWMosTgSAp-UAxHlOwP-wSqpPcUeS8DaJDws-uZBLw5GJU6UY1ckywKCv-iRxagOVdnTmI=> . The app is the ad placement.

 

Is Mobile Incremental?

 

Google's Adwords team sponsored a study that looked at whether or not clicks from mobile-search ads were incremental ... or is mobile-search advertising useless and should marketers be more worried about organic listings? And, the winner is ... surprise! Mobile-search ads matter. Read the stats <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3kh-H5d6WR3BHp_HLJ6OA333TygYjfFMRhzzqV5JbXMUh0sTpl99xOSpNjNNJM8p3Gw-Qa2unQn4I9fxepu-E2HrcXXUHfAw9Lqsk80gjYBYWF6HWIS5GNK-p8ql_m2KLRjzVmyEf_eoo5wTnKr9qzzhHG9d6THGR7jj4dkOgJYSJYRMZ_lakQu91LcjLFXmA4c=> .

 

Google Tube

 

Google's latest move in the online video space is a pitch to media companies to license their content for distribution online. The Wall Street Journal is reporting that if successful, Google would join Intel, Sony and Apple in trying to bring traditional TV programming to web-centric users. Although there wouldn't be a cost benefit for consumers, there will be better interfaces and more viewing options. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3kiaQnyZGL2wfATVfKKrUdNF8fzhAdxyHceIWoTcdrLn6zT4rIJXkhFbraZ7q-sa9lSg8IMl2XsuE_PzILXVc0ltV0jvhax5x4mY7PL7twLrSauEUoO9IbfxWjAWLRxOR7URsAFo0tVccrFcQ03xz319jcG-S_EqT28P0_DO8M-7eTnHoWR42J7W4_BDXLPGhB9nqtALgkydRDmJbjkoYdEStdzFtuYnRGQ=> .

 

Partnering For Audience

 

MediaMath announced a partnership with TiqIQ that it says will allow for retargeting of TiqIQ ticket buyers which adds, "TiqIQ powers ticket selling for more than 1,000 sports- and music-focused fan websites, including music publishers such as VoiceMediaGroup and other local and topical publishers like WashingtonPost, CoxMedia...". Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001w-mLBsOz3kivNGEWa06ji4g87cmgjhSSW-35lnH_NWuQ2zEt8BOYx6-0-xGVFaScniljUBJgwB5Ct-s2EOshAoSKGNY1StjVxfuG5xk2Vgego0bI6okTvWbFoaqGUyf3Uil46ThMWbNRxF94yqWwYfIxpHxw3B9o5hi8AilsOWelu_cOQG2tU--vBxqwoSkGbXg8fgpumTw=>  As a follow-up, MediaMath CEO Joe Zawadzki spoke to Businsess Insider and clarified his company's revenue while saying, basically, an IPO was possible but unlikely.

Criteo's Mobile Play

 

With yesterday's acquisition of Ad-X Tracking <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUaaxKioNC_l4VTc-AxMpSmW96y2IEkLjdxI0Yr8eJl9Htvd6RJp9N4IgMIhOzy9RC-a350sqdjWORdMVO9WRqJAlgWM75SltWY7gRV0vftaLIQ==>  in Europe, Criteo CEO JB Rudelle claims his company is "the one-stop display performance partner for both desktop and mobile devices" in spite of the inherent difficulties around targeting the mobile cookie versus targeting the desktop version. The release offers, "AD-X Tracking provides a solution for global brands to utilize in-app events and downloads to optimize their mobile campaign performance." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUaYwou1SAW9DElppWInszGAgx1nCRypQH3BPI8Qk8iR3S3oMfi0Z7TKo-_-icv-pChAII9_Id3X84-DzIcuICWtZZ57gXU8Arvrq34lf318Omw0kpdB1Oc28Ox2zUPCzcKE=>  Ad-X may also be seen more simply as a Criteo acqui-hire - mobile talent is in demand. A Criteo representative says that "the majority of the [9] new employees will be based in London and some going to other Criteo offices." Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

 

Ebay Exchange Strategy


Down Under, Ebay launched a localized private exchange with the help of its partner Rubicon Project. The press release tells part of the story, "eBay Advertising Australia has today created the country's largest private marketplace, via a partnership with Rubicon Project. The newly created marketplace gives brands access to over 7M unique visitors a month and the ability to programmatically trade on over a billion ad impressions." Read more. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUabZQapSj2RoJnc57hqBRl_BskzCuxbaB3Y0ieDZzT4nZ-C764fREty0EvIYNrLBEZimedbajypan9t4FwnfwD0Mi9aKKITGyY2yuiCI5quo3C-awUHSmSvpgxrBz6GX4yOIXVwKfq8ZGlMc85PdC8VVtlERM08AeDF2foNOZ-_-iAI-TSCHXIBvxCUkyxoVoO-r0VMkkhMxJXXVsqoaWGLq>  Ebay announced a Rubicon-powered <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUabAJiy5bDP-1qLd_jXamjLF2KFOKLZ_Xkt360nuD2U9Jhnnv557YW32Ow-NQos6OnflV-h8iDGngBComrZmvsInKnkyvnjvZlwsSQ9CuU3jTCE4-pSVQuitSh-qjzTu_ASTtDIIQH89HZEkMhcUlg6qg60PAgOkd5XW6OHcxcZcgrGTlyg0EdfbvioRlj7USdHKvrUWitI-tCo8oGYJg9f9qfvDNBFZmLY=>  exchange in the UK <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUaa7wV4nJVOjguZdE6QOCQ3JUKGtipAXm6h7EOT5ja9XWXbq4gtuK0h5rYH7NiP-5X7ICJwtsd2GX_lkA1Kt-_dA13YLCym86lNofV50kvkJutghGYGET-WIolhYCkazHRVyy8PpuJlrzc8fI1Te3Tif>  in September of 2012.    One can't help but wonder -is Rubicon Project a likely acquisition target for Ebay?

 

Ads And Pirates

 

Google and Microsoft pledged to follow new advertising guidelines, found here <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUaaQLQwJmOJ6DIAN5yrb_U1zK0oXkEx5REKcBubbCv9tUfJuy2cXtMDkJ9MKiEnQBBn3b-aF2iR7rLx1YpFI789k0n1iPZXcnc0OF4bU1rfueGmRN88f2DBjG6T2gKEgS9rTPBThMjK6KalzSioRoD6NMtiQGzoqVckIn7jx15poQS2c0UUva-Z8axSY5K124nQpmU4RV2vHO7QLtQhWjYfX> , in an attempt to reduce piracy, according to The Next Web. "By working across the industry, these best practices should help reduce the financial incentives for pirate sites by cutting off their revenue supply while maintaining a healthy Internet and promoting innovation," said Susan Molinari, Google's VP of Public Policy and Government Relations. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUaZ7mvquQ5olpKNM3YfQg8k7cqvOFJtutVCWGXZlXw9itmJPgSXDDH3cJOqYl6uAFLeYTRHEq7KTH9Cuq1zm1DAMfEhOgTW6xuaWL4U3U26okuPKkW8FurDbI3t9VmFkBdcNWKT532dcTYC_TUAETFetdJnt9TpxC-5N5wpOtzc4U7W_GD9wnQw_BHpjks7IuZHPO41VMwOtIeeT9h9Re6ym28wT_FbsTzWWG7vgl8IGMk6fPXzFQfi6-LcFwFiPEkNH0ktZ3Q1P6A==> . And, still more on The Hill. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUaYSvsSfjTjOX4aEyYcPAYlVG2H16Nm0K-sCw0TrhFLsc8jVvG2jeKJ8Dq45ivJaUM8lsN63-dpD_roXmPZ-8LkF0BxgbKkeaVYSQ36YBpZzMssupYt7TI5xe5jllvLj5I9SemjhWwZ1Zta1jhrpKUhukEYlhefxbAgVGN9SPuemjiwjCo6Dk8NNDwI2ndHkZKHMu8FHkQWmUMB_AUVa7dBAFhbX7tW-H5iK1g3pJmAJFACFBQOHkbWfl_-apZX7Iuc=> 

 

Ad Listing Battle

 

Google's ecommerce display ads - known as Product Listing Ads (PLA) - could be a threat to Amazon's revenue stream, according to Business Insider. The image ads not only grab more attention from consumers, they also push Amazon's ads lower down in the search results. Furthermore, Google may update the PLA system to allow for purchases directly from the ad, giving consumers an even more direct route to the product. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUaaw7XQjkPSROdXTZRZqu006rGhrcniPE87RHvy77ipyTSPxUiFsRuo0uYzjR0f3QtleqW6Hex5kCW0dp26Q-K4VSEfoBrdMXXg-GNSFl04iqimJxHo6_IiFPuldzf1lIFdYo-IlQqbaYKpA3mpE82HBDuO13ozdDryeMQAYyp937Q==> .

 

Do Not Track: In-Store Version

 

Tracking is tracking, online or off - right? Not according to the New York Times, which examined the difference in consumer sentiment about being tracked in-store versus online. The general consensus is that people feel more anonymous online and therefore don't feel it's as creepy as being "followed" in-store via their mobile phones. "The idea that you're being stalked in a store is, I think, a bit creepy, as opposed to, it's only a cookie - they don't really know who I am," said Robert Plant, a computer information systems professor at the University of Miami School of Business Administration. Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUab08uEk7qs4r_CcKas-_KP-CQTipTWc59RAFfJU8tXJn-gpGNkg5CZFwEsXkRfgvTdnONqWPtPYbUzJqIDB26vcse7vbwPXn7ewM9WZwVL6AX4_OL71SZAFbOl_oP_GXs2ebzhx9NrQNTzRw4pa6dQd36ZaGTycHidBazdzekgXPpsqVbaHAhFWIhNNJjNSIVTYbwrZje72pnN8kNmdapw0nCHU33SlfrBKKD3boju_6ieMJ1118N41> .

Cross-Screen Creative

 

For cross-screen creative junkies, yesterday's announcement by the IAB that its ad operations council had produced a final version of its HTML5 implementation guidance will come as joyous news. Read the release. <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUaawpjAp8wWGPhqACdd54igKQFEUklH0c4uPBa7jJhLBMqaOJIN6oWQQ1JhJMNLzK19UbElIH3UHkSeQ27UnqwIt90PjINYe1_PVRwomMUXOm9REGJgPgWRRCviSv2NOrNzw1xAu_GXo0YgoqUkjyr2jPZKrqIZT-wO1NGx7tsgk4bFRnWdQ8VBo_UmfldOWaMLlzq4GJF3296mXsWpREJTPsUbJN_ijO5E=>  File and ad unit size, code and asset compression and in-banner video advertising and animation are just some of the recommendations made for those using HTML5 to create web presences that work across devices. See the spec (PDF). <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUaa7cEjB1FqMibBaaIVBwlhFy0x35PgU_UmrqKMRO8hq1Y47TGUFjjHMMpFtYgRE_sKzFig6BSWLqflYaeN1EykL-pRO8iCgjxeh0lF9YXXg3rRMf4m3Bd10Zj3zLfDOY_D3EVqn-veC2w==> 

 

Ad Tech Kinks

 

In an iMedia Connection column, Upfront Digital's MIchael Hegarty runs through the problems stunting ad tech innovation and puts fragmentation at the top of the list. Trust and hierarchy also make the list. He writes, "Forcing each other to fit into labeled categories prevents meaningful collaboration toward finding the right solutions by introducing unnecessary constraints." Read more <http://r20.rs6.net/tn.jsp?e=001ZYgzTJWCUabx-2MPKl1Uje5kKoDxI84FfJGfMG_5Niaod4x8v3MioMGg2cOI_wpujoEjyxLhukUfO_BWpTzVghd1QnMvumyz4EUkXav2q-t7dQK2TKP0bwcXovHgHUIZphZtPJbEG2YpeGt6B1euwzV5-rF6o2v1> .
